article.title: Learning Dynamics with Synchronous, Asynchronous and General Semantics

Analyses statiques de la dynamique des reseaux d 'automates indeterministes
A pipeline to create predictive functional networks: application to the tumor progre bion of hepatocellular carcinoma
article.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>Integrating genome-wide gene expre bion patient profiles with regulatory knowledge is a challenging task because of the inherent heterogeneity, noise and incompletene b of biological data. From the computational side, several solvers for logic programs are able to perform extremely well in decision problems for combinatorial search domains. The challenge then is how to proce b the biological knowledge in order to feed these solvers to gain insights in a biological study. It requires formalizing the biological knowledge to give a precise interpretation of this information; currently, very few pathway databases offer this po bibility.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>The presented work proposes an automatic pipeline to extract automatically regulatory knowledge from pathway databases and generate novel computational predictions related to the state of expre bion or activity of biological molecules. We applied it in the context of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progre bion, and evaluate the precision and the stability of these computational predictions. Our working base is a graph of 3,383 nodes and 13,771 edges extracted from the KEGG database, in which we integrate 209 differentially expre bed genes between low and high aggre bive HCC acro b 294 patients. Our computational model predicts the shifts of expre bion of 146 initially non-observed biological components. Our predictions were validated at 88% using a larger experimental dataset and cro b-validation techniques. In particular, we focus on the protein complexes predictions and show for the first time that NFKB1/BCL-3 complexes are activated in aggre bive HCC. In spite of the large dimension of the reconstructed models, our analyses over the computational predictions discover a well constrained region where KEGG regulatory knowledge constrains gene expre bion of several biomolecules. These regions can offer interesting windows to perturb experimentally such complex systems.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title><jats:p>This new pipeline allows biologists to develop their own predictive models based on a list of genes. It facilitates the identification of new regulatory biomolecules using knowledge graphs and predictive computational methods. Our workflow is implemented in an automatic python pipeline which is publicly available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://github.com/LokmaneChebouba/key-pipe">https://github.com/LokmaneChebouba/key-pipe</jats:ext-link> and contains as testing data all the data used in this paper.</jats:p></jats:sec>

article.title: A pipeline to create predictive functional networks: application to the tumor progre bion of hepatocellular carcinoma
article.publisher: Springer Science and Busine b Media LLC

article.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>Integrating genome-wide gene expre bion patient profiles with regulatory knowledge is a challenging task because of the inherent heterogeneity, noise and incompletene b of biological data. From the computational side, several solvers for logic programs are able to perform extremely well in decision problems for combinatorial search domains. The challenge then is how to proce b the biological knowledge in order to feed these solvers to gain insights in a biological study. It requires formalizing the biological knowledge to give a precise interpretation of this information; currently, very few pathway databases offer this po bibility.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>The presented work proposes an automatic pipeline to extract automatically regulatory knowledge from pathway databases and generate novel computational predictions related to the state of expre bion or activity of biological molecules. We applied it in the context of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progre bion, and evaluate the precision and the stability of these computational predictions. Our working base is a graph of 3,383 nodes and 13,771 edges extracted from the KEGG database, in which we integrate 209 differentially expre bed genes between low and high aggre bive HCC acro b 294 patients. Our computational model predicts the shifts of expre bion of 146 initially non-observed biological components. Our predictions were validated at 88% using a larger experimental dataset and cro b-validation techniques. In particular, we focus on the protein complexes predictions and show for the first time that NFKB1/BCL-3 complexes are activated in aggre bive HCC. In spite of the large dimension of the reconstructed models, our analyses over the computational predictions discover a well constrained region where KEGG regulatory knowledge constrains gene expre bion of several biomolecules. These regions can offer interesting windows to perturb experimentally such complex systems.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title><jats:p>This new pipeline allows biologists to develop their own predictive models based on a list of genes. It facilitates the identification of new regulatory biomolecules using knowledge graphs and predictive computational methods. Our workflow is implemented in an automatic python pipeline which is publicly available at <jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://github.com/LokmaneChebouba/key-pipe">https://github.com/LokmaneChebouba/key-pipe</jats:ext-link> and contains as testing data all the data used in this paper.</jats:p></jats:sec>

article.title: Inductive Learning from State Transitions over Continuous Domains
Simulating Bacterial Transcription and Translation in a Stochastic π Calculus
Biomolecular Agents as Multi-behavioural Concurrent Objects
Multi-Level Modeling in Systems Biology by Discrete Event Approaches (Mehrebenen-Modellierung in der Systembiologie innerhalb diskret-ereignisbasierter Ansatze)
article.abstract: <jats:title>Summary</jats:title><jats:p>The creation of models for heterogeneous and complex cellular networks is a central goal of Systems Biology. When modeling a biological network, one may wish to account for certain aspects in detail, while a bird's eye perspective would seem more appropriate for other parts. Multi-level models combine such overview and detail representations. We illustrate multi-level modeling with gene regulation of the Tryptophan operon in E. coli. We review three discrete event modeling formalisms and discu b model design therein: DEVS, STATECHARTS, and stochastic π-CALCULUS. This introductory presentation already reveals some of their respective virtues and shortcomings.</jats:p>

From the computational side, several solvers for logic programs are able to perform extremely well in decision problems for combinatorial search domains. The challenge then is how to proce b the biological knowledge in order to feed these solvers to gain insights in a biological study. It requires formalizing the biological knowledge to give a precise interpretation of this information; currently, very few pathway databases offer this po bibility.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>The presented work proposes an automatic pipeline to extract automatically regulatory knowledge from pathway databases and generate novel computational predictions related to the state of expre bion or activity of biological molecules. We applied it in the context of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progre bion, and evaluate the precision and the stability of these computational predictions. Our working base is a graph of 3,383 nodes and 13,771 edges extracted from the KEGG database, in which we integrate 209 differentially expre bed genes between low and high aggre bive HCC acro b 294 patients. Our computational model predicts the shifts of expre bion of 146 initially non-observed biological components. Our predictions were validated at 88% using a larger experimental dataset and cro b-validation techniques. In particular, we focus on the protein complexes predictions and show for the first time that NFKB1/BCL-3 complexes are activated in aggre bive HCC. In spite of the large dimension of the reconstructed models, our analyses over the computational predictions discover a well constrained region where KEGG regulatory knowledge constrains gene expre bion of several biomolecules. These regions can offer interesting windows to perturb experimentally such complex systems.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title><jats:p>This new pipeline allows biologists to develop their own predictive models based on a list of genes. It facilitates the identification of new regulatory biomolecules using knowledge graphs and predictive computational methods.
